plugins.name: Coordinate
plugins.description:
A simple plugin for quickly targeting nodes and extracting key positional data (X, Y, width, height) for use in other applications.


_Built using [The DataFace's Figma plugin template](https://github.com/the-dataface/figma-plugin-svelte-vite)_


How-to


1. Prefix desired nodes with a uniform string (e.g. `COORDINATE.` or `#` or `@`).

2. Once the plugin is initialized, enter that string in the search box (the default is `COORDINATE`) and run the command.

3. The positional data will show up below in the plugin's UI as JSON. You can download the results directly using the download button in the top-right corner of the results box.

accepted.name: The DataFace
accepted.description: A digital agency, specializing in data visualization

plugins.description:
This app takes your Figma design tokens, such as color, typography, effect, and spacing, and generates code outputs in over 10 different formats, including CSS, SCSS, Tailwind, TypeScript, Shopify Liquid, Swift, and more. Additionally, it allows you to export Local Styles definitions as CSS. Designed to streamline your design-to-code workflow, it‚Äôs an essential tool for designers and developers alike.


How Does It Work?

1.Select either Local Variables or Local Styles to begin.

2.Choose the tokens you want to generate code for.

3.Pick your desired output format (e.g., CSS, Tailwind).

4.Hit the Copy button to get your code.


That‚Äôs it! Transforming your tokens into ready-to-use code is now just a few clicks away.

plugins.name: Layer Renaming
plugins.description:
Layer Renaming: Streamline Your Workflow with Effortless Layer Management


Revolutionize your Figma workflow with Layer Renaming, the ultimate solution for efficient layer organization. This powerful plugin offers:


1. Selective Layer Renaming: Choose specific layers and modify their names with ease.

2. Time-Based Ordering: Automatically arrange layers based on their creation time for a logical naming sequence.

3. Customizable Naming Patterns: Input a primary layer name and add custom symbols or numbering as desired.

4. One-Click Renaming: Instantly rename multiple layers with a single confirmation, saving you valuable time.


Whether you're working on complex designs or maintaining consistency across projects, Layer Renaming simplifies your process, allowing you to focus on what truly matters - your creative vision.


Boost your productivity today with Layer Renaming - the fast, intuitive, and indispensable tool for every Figma user!

plugins.name: Filla - Color Palette Extractor
plugins.description:
What it does

Filla dives through every nested layer; shapes, text, vectors, icons, and pulls out every unique solid and gradient fill or stroke. It then drops those colours into a neat swatch grid on-canvas, each labelled with its HEX value. One click turns the whole set into named Figma Color Styles.


How to use:

1. Select any parent frame, component, or section.

2. Run Filla ‚Üí watch the deep scan.

3. Review the generated palette.

4. Hit Create Styles to add them to your library.


Why it‚Äôs handy

‚Ä¢ Kick-start a design system by surfacing legacy colours.

‚Ä¢ Audit messy files and spot duplicates fast.

‚Ä¢ Hand off a clear colour spec to developers in seconds.

accepted.description: designer and craftsman

plugins.name: Variable Agent
plugins.description:
Variable Agent

The plugin is designed to facilitate the management of variable collections within Figma. At the moment, it allows users to copy and paste variable collections, making it easier to manage design tokens and other variable data across different projects and files.


Current Capabilities

- View Variable Collections: Users can view all local variable collections available in Figma.

- Copy Collections: Users can select a variable collection and copy it to their clipboard.

- Paste Collections: Users can paste the copied variable collection into another document or project.


Steps to Use the Plugin in Figma

1. Open the Plugin: Launch the plugin from the Figma plugins menu.

2. View Collections: Upon opening, the plugin will automatically fetch and display all available variable collections.

4. Select a Collection: Use the dropdown menu to select the collection you wish to copy.

5. Copy the Collection: Click the "Copy Collection" button to copy the selected variable collection to your clipboard.

6. Paste the Collection: Navigate to the document where you want to paste the collection, launch the plugin, and click the "Paste Collection" button.

7. Check Status Messages: Monitor the status messages displayed in the plugin for feedback on your actions.


Limitations

- Draft file Support: If you copy a collection with multiple modes, and paste in a file in your draft, it won't work. This is because draft file only support 1 mode.


- Aliased variable collections: The plugin does not currently support pasting variable collections with aliased variables. Aliased variables are those that reference other collection. It will recognize the alias but will not be able to resolve the reference.

accepted.name: Raymond
accepted.description: Strategic Product Designer and Creator of Frames and Divs.

plugins.tagline: Copy and paste variable collection across files and projects

plugins.name: Clickma: ClickUp to Figma Sync
plugins.description:
Clickma eliminates rework and duplication by keeping design and project documentation seamlessly aligned in one unified workflow. It ties relevant ClickUp tickets directly to the Figma sections referenced, so Designers, Developers, Product Managers, and QAs can easily find what they need. See a video demo here.


Some key features include:

  1. Ticket import: Display Clickup Tickets in your Figma canvas.
  2. Jump to ticket: See all imported tickets in a list and jump to their location in your figma file.
  3. Search ticket in list view: Basic users can search by title and Clickup ID. Premium users can also search by Clickup status or assignee.
  4. DevMode Compatible: DevMode users can jump to ticket and see the list view.
  5. Sync tickets: Basic users can sync tickets individually, while Premium users can bulk sync tickets with just 1-click.
  6. Ticket link (premium): Open your tickets in your browser from list view, DevMode or the tickets you import.
  7. Edit tickets (premium): Edit ticket title, status and description within Figma and sync back to ClickUp.


Check more details our website clickma.tech


We are in active development, if you have suggestions for improvement, feedback or need help please contact us at support@clickma.tech

  1. Ticket import: Display Clickup Tickets in your Figma canvas.
  2. Jump to ticket: See all imported tickets in a list and jump to their location in your figma file.
  3. Search ticket in list view: Basic users can search by title and Clickup ID. Premium users can also search by Clickup status or assignee.
  4. DevMode Compatible: DevMode users can jump to ticket and see the list view.
  5. Sync tickets: Basic users can sync tickets individually, while Premium users can bulk sync tickets with just 1-click.
  6. Ticket link (premium): Open your tickets in your browser from list view, DevMode or the tickets you import.
  7. Edit tickets (premium): Edit ticket title, status and description within Figma and sync back to ClickUp.


Check more details our website clickma.tech

plugins.name: Variables ‚Üí Text Styles
plugins.description:
Easily Apply Variables to Your Text Styles

Tired of manually assigning variables to text styles? Variables to Text Styles plugin lets you streamline this process by syncing your variables to existing text styles.


How It Works

You'll need existing text styles and typography variables ready to go, then follow these steps:


  1. Create text objects
  2. Apply variables to the text layers' properties
  3. Name the text layers to match their corresponding text style. If your styles are in folders, include the full path using '/' (e.g., folder/subfolder/style)
  4. Run the plugin
  5. Select your text layers. If you make changes, you'll need to reselect them.
  6. Click "Update Text Styles" to apply the variables


Important Notes

  1. If you modify your text properties while the plugin is open, reselect them to refresh the updates.
  2. This plugin does not convert text layers into styles, allowing you to continue making adjustments.

plugins.name: Layer Manager
plugins.description:
Layer Manager is designed to improve your workflow by providing quick access to important layer management functions. 


This plugin focuses on three primary operations: listing layers, controlling layer visibility, and renaming layers. 


Getting Started

  1. Open your Figma design file.
  2. Select the layers or frames you want to manage.
  3. Search for the Layer Manager plugin from the Figma plugin menu.
  4. Launch the plugin. 


Basic Operations

Viewing Layers:

After launching the plugin with your desired layers or frames selected, you'll see a list of all the layers within your selection.


Toggling Layer Visibility

Individual Layers:

  1. Find the layer you want to toggle in the list.
  2. Click the visibility icon next to the layer name to show or hide it.
  3. The change will be immediately reflected in your Figma design.

All Layers:

  1. Use the "Hide all" button to hide all layers in the list at once.
  2. Use the "Show all" button to make all layers in the list visible.


Renaming Layers:

  1. Locate the layer you want to rename in the list.
  2. Click on the layer name to enter edit mode.
  3. Type the new name for the layer.
  4. Press Enter or click outside the input field to confirm the new name.


Refreshing the Layer List:

If you make changes to your selection in the Figma file while the plugin is open:

  1. Click the "Refresh layers" button in the plugin interface.
  2. The layer list will update to reflect your current selection in the Figma document.


Searching Layers:

  1. Click on the search bar at the top of the layer list in the plugin interface and type in your search term. This could be: a layer name or a layer type (e.g., "rectangle," "text," or "group").
  2. As you type, the layer list would dynamically update to show only the layers that match your search criteria.
  3. To clear the search and see all layers again, simply delete your search term.


Tips for Efficient Use

  1. Start with a focused selection in your Figma file to manage specific groups of layers more effectively.
  2. Use the bulk hide/show actions to quickly toggle visibility for comparing different versions of your design.
  3. Regularly refresh the layer list if you're making changes in your Figma file while the plugin is open.
  4. Rename layers directly from the plugin to maintain consistent naming conventions without switching contexts.

accepted.name: Soliudeen Ogunsola
accepted.description: Product Designer.

plugins.tagline: A better way to view, hide, and rename your design layers.

plugins.name: African Name Generator
plugins.description:
African Name Generator Plugin


What It Does

The African Name Generator plugin helps you quickly add authentic African names to your designs. You can generate and insert first names, last names, or full names from Nigeria, Kenya, Ghana, South Africa, and Ethiopia.


How to Use It

1. Open the Plugin: Find and launch the African Name Generator plugin in your Figma plugins menu.

2. Select Parameters:

- Country: Choose Nigeria, Kenya, Ghana, South Africa, Ethiopia, Egypt, Senegal, Uganda, Tanzania, Morocco, and Cameroon.

- Gender: Pick male or female.

- Name Type: Select first name, last name, or full name.

3. Generate Name: Click the "Generate Name" button. The name will appear in the plugin.

4. Insert Name:

- Select a text layer in your Figma file.

- Click the "Insert Name" button. The plugin will insert the name into the selected text layer.


Limitations

- Name List: The names come from a fixed list. Not every African name is included.

- Font Support: The plugin uses fonts available in Figma. Ensure the desired font is available.

- Single Text Layer: Insert names into one text layer at a time. Repeat the process for multiple layers.


The African Name Generator plugin allows you to easily add real African names to your designs.

accepted.name: Joseph Kalu
accepted.description: I am a fintech and crypto product designer

137859.release_notes:
## [2.7.1] - 2025-06-15

### üêõ Critical Bug Fixes
- **Fixed standalone node parsing**: Now correctly parses both standalone node definitions and edge connections
  - **Issue**: Nodes were displaying IDs (Q, C, T) instead of text labels ("Pick a drink", "Coffee", "Tea")
  - **Root cause**: Parser only processed edge connections, ignored standalone node definitions
  - **Solution**: Enhanced parser to handle both `Q{Pick a drink}` definitions AND `Q --> C` connections
- **Complete syntax support**: All node types now correctly display text labels
  - `[Rectangle text]` ‚úÖ
  - `{Diamond text}` ‚úÖ 
  - `(Ellipse text)` ‚úÖ
  - `([Ellipse text])` ‚úÖ (both ellipse syntaxes supported)

### üîß Code Quality Improvements
- **Removed dead code**: Eliminated unused `_calculateLegacyLayout()` function (39 lines removed)
- **Optimized function signatures**: Removed unused `levels` parameter from `resolveNodeCollisions()`
- **Consolidated configuration**: Created unified `SHAPE_CONFIG` object for all node types
  - **Before**: Scattered across `getShapeTextConfig()`, `getNodeColors()`, `getShapeType()`
  - **After**: Single source of truth with `SHAPE_CONFIG` and `ROLE_COLORS` objects
- **Enhanced documentation**: Added comprehensive JSDoc comments for all public functions
- **Improved linting**: Created `.eslintignore` to exclude generated `code.js` file

### üß™ Testing & Validation
- **Extensive test coverage**: Verified with 5 diverse Mermaid test cases
  - Mixed node types with edge labels ‚úÖ
  - Left-right layouts with long text ‚úÖ
  - Complex branching decision trees ‚úÖ
  - Simple linear processes ‚úÖ
  - Multiple start/end points ‚úÖ
- **Version logging**: Added console logging to verify latest code is running
- **Clean builds**: All code compiles without errors and passes linting

plugins.name: Multi-Link Copy
plugins.description:
Multi-Link Copy


Multi-Link Copy is designed to streamline the process of copying multiple frame or component links at once. If you're working on a large-scale design project, you may need to share or document the locations of multiple frames or components within a your file.


Instead of manually copying each link one by one, this plugin allows you to select multiple components or frames and generate their links in bulk. The links are copied to your clipboard in separate lines, making it easy to paste them into a spreadsheet, text file, or any document where you need to store or share those links.


What the Plugin Does:


Batch Copying of Links:

  1. The plugin generates URLs for selected components or frames within the current Figma file.
  2. Each link is a direct reference to the specific node (frame or component) inside the Figma file.
  3. These links are copied to your clipboard and can be pasted into any document, where each URL will appear on its own line in the order of your layer hierarchy in your Figma file (top layers first).


Use Case:

  1. When you need to share links to multiple frames or components in one go, especially for documentation, design reviews, developer hand-offs, or tracking design updates.
  2. Useful for project managers, designers, and developers who need quick access to the location of specific elements within a Figma file.


---


How to Use the Plugin:


1. Enter Figma File URL

  1. After launching the plugin, you will be prompted to enter the URL of your Figma file.
  2. This is required to extract the file key that‚Äôs necessary for generating URLs for the selected frames or components.
  3. This data is used temporarily by the plugin and never saved, read, or accessed by anyone.
  4. To get the URL, open the Figma file in your browser and copy the link from the address bar. It should look something like: https://www.figma.com/file/{fileKey}/Your-File-Name.


2. Selecting Elements

  1. Select the components, frames, or any other nodes you want to generate links for.


3. Copy Links

  1. Click "Copy Links" and a notification will appear confirming how many links were copied.
  2. The links are already copied to your clipboard, formatted one per line.


4. Paste Links

  1. Go to any document where you want to paste the links (e.g., Excel, Google Sheets, Notion, Slack, etc.).
  2. Each link will populate a new line or row in the document in the order of your layers in Figma (top layers first).


5. Celebrate üéâ


---


What You Can Expect:


Fast Bulk Link Generation: Select as many frames or components as needed, and the plugin will generate URLs for all selected items instantly.


Easy Copy and Paste: Once the plugin runs, the links are automatically copied to the clipboard. You don‚Äôt need to open a separate window or click additional buttons. Simply paste the links wherever needed.


---


Example Output


After running the plugin, if you've selected 3 components, pasting into a document will give something like this:


https://www.figma.com/file/{fileKey}/?node-id=123:456

https://www.figma.com/file/{fileKey}/?node-id=789:1011

https://www.figma.com/file/{fileKey}/?node-id=112:1314


Each URL points directly to the specific frame or component within the Figma file.


---


Limitations:


The plugin needs the Figma file URL to extract the fileKey, which is a unique identifier for your Figma file. The fileKey allows it to accurately generate direct links to the frames or components you select.


The URL is only used temporarily to retrieve this key, ensuring privacy and security. The plugin does not store any information. Keep in mind, only users with access to your files can view or use the generated links.


About fileKeys: A fileKey is part of the URL that uniquely identifies each Figma file. It's essential for referencing the correct file when generating links for components or frames. To understand more about how fileKeys work and where they are located in your Figma URL, you can visit Figma's documentation here.
plugins.tagline: Batch copy mutliple frame links at a time

plugins.name: WCAG Line Length
plugins.description:
Make your text more accessible with automatic line length optimization.


This plugin helps you comply with WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.4.8, which recommends limiting line lengths to 80 characters or less. Long lines of text can be difficult to read and navigate, especially for users with cognitive disabilities or visual impairments.


üìê Key features:

  1. Check text elements against WCAG guidelines
  2. Automatically fix line lengths by adding strategic line breaks
  3. Works with any text layer or text box
  4. Supports multiple text selections
  5. Preserves your original text styling


üí¨ How to use:

  1. Select any text layers you want to check
  2. Click "Check Selection" to identify issues
  3. Click "Fix" to automatically adjust line lengths


Perfect for:

  1. UX/UI designers
  2. Accessibility specialists
  3. Content designers
  4. Anyone creating accessible digital experiences


Stay compliant with accessibility standards while maintaining clean, readable designs.
plugins.tagline: "Make your designs accessible by optimizing text line lengths to WCAG standards"

plugins.name: Component Swapper
plugins.description:
Replaces the selected objects with similarly named objects from the library.


For example, if you need to replace one icon set with another. Works within any selected object including components.


The objects should differ by the beginning of their names, while the rest of the name should remain the same.

For example: a_icon ‚Üí b_icon or filled_icon ‚Üí outlined_icon.


To use it, you need to:

  1. Enter the library ID in the settings (‚öôÔ∏è)
  2. Enter your access token
  3. Enter a name fragment of the objects to be replaced and a fragment of the new objects' names
  4. Select the objects you want to replace and run the plugin


How to find the library ID

In your library, click Share and copy the link.

The library ID is the part that comes after /design/ in the URL:

www.figma.com/design/{file-id}/unnecessary_part_of_the_link


How to find the access token

Read the article in Figma‚Äôs documentation
plugins.tagline: Replaces the selected objects with similarly named objects from the library
